Table of Contents

Class CachedAttribute

Namespace
osu.Framework.Allocation
Assembly
osu.Framework.dll

An attribute that may be attached to a class, interface, field, or property definitions of a Drawable to indicate that the value should be cached as a dependency. Cached values may be resolved through BackgroundDependencyLoaderAttribute or ResolvedAttribute.

[MeansImplicitUse]
[AttributeUsage(AttributeTargets.Class|AttributeTargets.Property|AttributeTargets.Field|AttributeTargets.Interface, AllowMultiple = true, Inherited = false)]
public class CachedAttribute : Attribute

Remarks

The behaviour of this attribute differs in meaning depending on the type of member it is placed on.

  • In the case of fields and properties, the dependency will be cached for the children of the drawable that contains the field or property.

    Unless specified differently by Type, the dependency will be cached using the field/property value's concrete (most-derived) type. See the examples section of the Type property documentation for further information.

  • Instances of classes annotated with CachedAttribute will cache themselves for their own children. Unless specified differently by Type, the dependency will be cached using the type at the point where the CachedAttribute was declared.

    Note that while the CachedAttribute itself is not inherited, derived class instances will still cache themselves using the base class. See the examples section of the Type property documentation for further information.

  • If a class implements an interface annotated with CachedAttribute, then instances of that class will cache themselves for their own children using the interface type. As with classes, the CachedAttribute is not inherited between interfaces either, but an instance of a class will cache itself to children using all cacheable interface types that it implements.

Constructors

CachedAttribute()

Identifies a member to be cached to a DependencyContainer.

public CachedAttribute()

CachedAttribute(Type, string)

Identifies a member to be cached to a DependencyContainer.

public CachedAttribute(Type type = null, string name = null)

Parameters

type Type

The type to cache the member as.

name string

The name to identify the member as in the cache.

Fields

Name

The name to identify this member with.

public string Name

Field Value

string

Remarks

If the member is cached with a custom CacheInfo that provides a parent, the name is automatically inferred from the field/property.

Type

The type to cache the value as. If null, the type depends on the type of member that the attribute is placed on:

  • In the case of fields and properties, the attribute will use the concrete/most-derived type of the field/property's value.
  • In the case of classes and interfaces, the attribute will use the class/interface type on which the CachedAttribute was directly placed.
public Type Type

Field Value

Type

Examples

In the case of fields and properties, if this value is null on the following field definition: 

[Cached]
 private BaseType obj = new DerivedType();
then the cached type will be DerivedType.

In the case of classes, given the following structure: 

[Cached]
 public class A { }

public class B : A { }
the following things will happen:
  • Instances of A will cache themselves to children using type A.
  • Instances of B will cache themselves to children using type A.
  • Instances of B will not cache themselves to children using type B. To achieve that effect, the CachedAttribute has to be repeated on class B.
CachedAttribute placed in interface inheritance hierarchies follows analogous rules to the ones described above for classes.
